medium: Queen Conch (lobatus gigas) with (modern) red paint highlighting incisions
creditline: Museum purchase, Mary Trumbull Adams Art Fund and gift of Gillett G. Griffin

texts.textentryhtml:
February 5, 1970, José Palomeque sold to Gillett G. Griffin (1928-2016), Princeton, NJ [1]; 2014, sold to the Princeton University Art Museum.

Notes:
[1] According to Griffin’s Notebook 5-14.

This shell plaque depicts a seated male individual dressed in a loincloth, hip-skirt, and cloth head-wrappings. Recesses in areas where Maya nobility wore jade ornaments likely once held jade inlays. The figure faces the viewer’s left, which in Maya art is a conventional orientation for scenes of Maya royalty or secondary lords. This pose—with the right arm held across the torso—normally depicts a lord receiving tribute or holding audience. Some similar shell plaques include hieroglyphs naming the person portrayed. The lack of royal titles in such inscriptions—and one example that refers to a youth—suggests that such plaques were made as gifts for young nobles who took a post called sajal, one rank below ajaw, lord.

bibliography.boilertext: Gerald Berjonneau, Emile Deletaille, and Jean-Louis Sonnery, Rediscovered Masterpieces of Mesoamerica: Mexico-Guatemala-Honduras (Boulogne: Editions Arts, 1985).
bibliography.citation: Gerald Berjonneau, Emile Deletaille, and Jean-Louis Sonnery, Rediscovered Masterpieces of Mesoamerica: Mexico-Guatemala-Honduras (Boulogne: Editions Arts, 1985)., cat. no. 394 (illus., image flipped)

bibliography.boilertext: Marilyn M. Goldstein and Lourdes Suárez Diez, Conchas Precolombinas: Mesoamerican Art Created from Seashells (Brookville, Hillwood Art Museum, Longwood Island University, C.W. Post Campus, 1997).
bibliography.citation: Marilyn M. Goldstein and Lourdes Suárez Diez, Conchas Precolombinas: Mesoamerican Art Created from Seashells (Brookville, Hillwood Art Museum, Longwood Island University, C.W. Post Campus, 1997)., cat. no. 186 (illus.)

bibliography.boilertext: "Acquisitions of the Princeton University Art Museum 2014", Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 74 (2015): p. 55-77.
bibliography.citation: "Acquisitions of the Princeton University Art Museum 2014", Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 74 (2015): p. 55-77., p. 59 (color illus.)
